results.definition: a style of architecture developed in northern France that spread throughout Europe between the 12th and 16th centuries; characterized by slender vertical piers and counterbalancing buttresses and by vaulting and pointed arches
as if belonging to the Middle Ages; old-fashioned and unenlightened

characterized by gloom and mystery and the grotesque
extinct East Germanic language of the ancient Goths; the only surviving record being fragments of a 4th-century translation of the Bible by Bishop Ulfilas
characteristic of the style of type commonly used for printing German
